content.text: State the reading on the stopclock
reading =   .........  minutes   .........  seconds
Calculate the time, in seconds, for one rotation of the blades
time for one rotation =   .........  s
Later in the day, the blades of the wind turbine are found to take 15 s to rotate on
The tip of the blade travels in a circle of circumference \(75 \text{m}\)
Calculate the average speed of the tip of the blade
average speed =   .........  m/s
A wind turbine can be seen through the window of the IGCSE Physics class laboratory shown in Fig. 1.1
The blades on the wind turbine are turning slowly, so a student uses a laboratory stopclock to time 40 rotations of the blades
Fig. 1.2 shows the stopclock after 40 rotations of the blades
Fig. 1.2
The mass of \(35 \text{cm}^3\) of mercury is measured as \(476 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density of mercury. Give the unit
density =   .........
The density of water is much less than the density of mercury
How does the mass of \(35 \text{cm}^3\) of water compare with the mass of \(35 \text{cm}^3\) of mercury?
Tick one box
mass of water is less than mass of mercury
mass of water is the same as mass of mercury
mass of water is greater than mass of mercury
What happens to the mass of the mercury? Tick one box
decreases
stays the same
increases
What happens to the density of the mercury? Tick one box
decreases
stays the same
increases
The mercury in a thermometer expands when it is heated
State what is meant by the _moment_ of a force
What two things can be said about the moments caused by the boy and by the girl?
There are four forces acting on the plank when it is in equilibrium. Three of the forces are:
- the weight of the girl
- the weight of the plank
- the force provided by the boy
1. Where does the fourth force act?
2. What is the direction of this force?
A plank balances horizontally on a log of wood, which acts as a pivot
A girl sits on one end of the plank, and a boy pushes down on the other end to keep the plank horizontal. Fig. 3.1 shows this arrangement
State what is meant by the _frequency_ of the vibration of a vibrating object
Explain how a sound is produced and transmitted when the prongs are vibrating
After the tuning fork was struck on the solid surface, the sound from the tuning fork gradually gets quieter
State what happens to the tuning fork to cause this
Another tuning fork is marked with \(256\mathrm{Hz}\), to indicate its frequency
State how the sound from this tuning fork compares with the sound from the tuning fork in Fig. 4.1
Fig. 4.1 shows a tuning fork. Its frequency is indicated by the number on the handle
When the tuning fork is struck on a solid surface, the prongs A and B vibrate as indicated by the arrows

Fig. 7.1 is a ray diagram for a converging lens
The compass is placed to the left of the N pole of the magnet. Its needle points in the direction shown by the arrow
Four other positions are indicated around the magnet, each marked by a circle
In each circle, draw an arrow to indicate the direction in which the compass needle would point at each of these positions. Other magnetic fields can be ignored.
Five pieces of metal are placed, in turn, near the S pole of the magnet
In the table below tick the box that states what happens to each of the different metals. An example has been given to help you
